Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Taiwan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Camerron M. Crowder of Oregon State University to conduct a research project, entitled "A window in time: impacts of increased seawater temperature on hormonal fluctuations in reproducing Taiwanese corals," during the summer of 2012 at National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in Checheng Village of Pingtung County, Taiwan. The host scientist is Dr. Tung-Yung Fan.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to provide insight into the initiation of reproduction in corals and to expand current understanding of the impacts of increased seawater temperature on hormone fluctuations and reproductive timing. Investigations include analysis of hormone fluctuations and larval release in normal and increased seawater temperatures, making possible estimates of coral reproduction resilience in the future.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research activities at the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium (NMMBA) in Checheng, Taiwan focused on examining the marine ecology and physiology of reproductive timing in the coral Pocillopora damicornis. I chose Taiwan and NMMBA in order to be able to work with Dr. Tung-Yung Fan, a leader in the field of coral reproduction ecology. My activities at NMMBA involved collecting corals via SCUBA and observing/quantifying their reproductive output (number of larvae released during their monthly reproductive cycle). Specifically, I was interested in the effects of temperature on the timing of larvae release. During the reproductive cycle, at different lunar phases (new moon, 1st quarter, full moon, and 2nd quarter), I collected tissue samples for hormonal and transcriptomic analysis back at my home institution, Oregon State University (OSU).  I collected lots of interesting data and I am currently preparing a manuscript for publication on my findings.

Participating in the EAPSI program and working at NMMBA was a successful and positive experience. During my time at NMMBA I worked with graduate students and interns in the Fan lab on multiple projects and collaborated with visiting scientist conducting research on larval physiology and settlement. I was highly productive during the program and was able to interact and build connections with multiple people within my field of coral biology. Traveling throughout Taiwan was nothing short of magical. I thoroughly benefited from the international experience and was able to be flexible and open to new and enriching opportunities. The staff at NSF and Summer Institute Taiwan (SIT) were overwhelmingly supportive and helpful, everything was well organized, efficient, and a ton of fun. I would highly recommend this program to other graduate students.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2012
Modified by: Camerron Crowder
